Abstract 26 27 Background 28 In March 2020 the World Health Organisation (WHO) released a Global Research Roadmap in an effort to 29 coordinate and accelerate the global research response to combat COVID-19 based on deliberations of 400 30 experts across the world. Three months on, the disease and our understanding have both evolved significantly.

As we now tackle a pandemic in very different contexts and with increased knowledge, we sought to build on 32 the work of the WHO to gain a more current and global perspective on these initial priorities.

We undertook a mixed methods study seeking the views of the global research community to i) assess which 36 of the early WHO roadmap priorities are still most pressing; ii) understand whether they are still valid in 37 different settings, regions or countries; and iii) identify any new emerging priorities. 38 39 Thematic analysis of the significant body of combined data shows the WHO roadmap is globally relevant, 40 however, new important priorities have emerged, in particular, pertinent to low and lower-middle income 41 countries (less resourced countries), where health systems are under significant competing pressures. We also 42 found a shift from prioritising vaccine and therapeutic development towards a focus on assessing the 43 effectiveness, risks, benefits and trust in the variety of public health interventions and measures. Our findings 44 also provide insight into temporal nature of these research priorities, highlighting the urgency of research that 45 can only be undertaken within the period of virus transmission, as well as other important research questions 46 but which can be answered outside the transmission period. Both types of studies are key to help combat this 47 pandemic but also importantly to ensure we are better prepared for the future.

body_text.text: The aim of the open-ended survey was to determine whether there are new priorities that were not included 108 in the original WHO roadmap or the AAS survey findings. These written comments were imported into NVivo 109 qualitative data analysis package and we undertook a pragmatic thematic content analysis. Analysing the data 110 from the workshops allowed a further open consideration of current research priorities as this step expanded 111 beyond the limitation that the survey had of asking questions within the framework of the WHO roadmap.

body_text.text: Following the methodology established after the first workshop (7) we compiled a dataset by transcribing the 113 spoken and written comments from each workshop. A coding framework was generated through an inductive 114 and then deductive approach, following the same categories used in the survey.

In total, 1,528 individuals completed the online survey and 2,559 attended the workshops, from across 137 The survey results (Table 1) shows how priorities were ranked across the immediate and longer term within 125 the WHO categories. body_text.section: Cross-cutting

body_text.text: These data suggest that that original WHO COVID-19 Research Roadmap remains broadly globally applicable.
Here we also show which research questions require the most emphasis and also that potential new priorities 147 have emerged that were not within the initial roadmap.

Consideration of both immediate and long-term priorities is important to address this specific pandemic and 182 to better prepare for the future. There are studies that need ongoing transmission, at a high enough rate to 183 answer the question they set. These might be essential for this pandemic, for example clinical trials to 184 . FIGREF6.text: suggested priorities reflect the progress of the pandemic and acquisition of knowledge as to where 150 the gaps lie; notably research in children, pregnancy, long-term health impacts of the disease and that there 151 is a strong call for research that assesses the effectiveness of public health measurers put into place across 152 the globe to reduce transmission of this virus. These were alongside a demand for greater social science 153 research to determine public perception, and better ways to change behaviours and build trust. We also 154 identified a range of new priorities relating to addressing COVID-19 in lower resource settings, where multiple 155 pressures including ongoing endemic infectious diseases and other co-morbidities are competing within the 156 health and policy systems for limited resources. priority headings, and this meant that some headings (for example the animal human interface) had relatively survey and this may have influenced the ranking given by respondents. The workshops however were open 163 and purposefully invited researchers to make whatever comments they wanted in regard to where current 164 research priorities lie. Therefore, taken together we suggest that these data support the importance of the 165 WHO research roadmap approach and highlights where funders and researcher should be placing emphasis 166 as well as identifying potential new areas that should be tackled within this pandemic. 167 168 Given that no really effective anti-virals have yet been identified, and with the prospect of a globally accessible 169 vaccine being still some way off, the only interventions that have been deployable by countries are public 170 health measures to prevent transmission. It is therefore unsurprising then that the survey respondents and 171 workshop participants ranked highly the need for further studies to evaluate the value of such measures as 172 well as studies on other potential interventions as they arise. 173 174 These studies must be undertaken as quickly as possible if we are to gain evidence now on just how effective 175 measures such as lockdown, handwashing and social distancing are on reducing transmission. These studies 176 are needed in highly varied social contexts to understand the relative risks and benefits. The need for social 177 science research and mixed methods came through very strongly, with an emphasis on determining how to 178 gain the trust and successfully deliver public health messages. This needs evidence-based community 179 engagement strategies; tested and evaluated everywhere.

Here we have suggested a matrix that groups these priorities which might help guide 194 resource allocation and research planning (Fig 1). This complements ongoing work by the UK Collaborative 195 on Development Research and Global Research Collaboration for Infectious Disease Preparedness to map 196 research funding against the WHO roadmap priorities to enable funders and researchers identify gaps and 197 opportunities and inform future research investments or coordination needs (8).
